title: 108_s348
content: The "Make College Affordable Act of 2003" establishes deductions for higher education expenses under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Act limits the amount allowed as a deduction for qualified tuition and related expenses for taxpayers in any taxable year. The "Make College Affordable Act of 2003" limits deductions for higher education expenses in taxable years 2003 and beyond to $8,000 and $12,000 respectively, based on modified adjusted gross income. The "Make College Affordable Act of 2003" limits deductions for higher education expenses based on modified adjusted gross income, with specific thresholds for single and joint filers. The "Make College Affordable Act of 2003" limits deductions for higher education expenses based on adjusted gross income, with inflation adjustments for taxable years after 2003. The "Make College Affordable Act of 2003" limits deductions for higher education expenses based on adjusted gross income, with inflation adjustments for taxable years after 2003. The act specifies the calculation for the cost-of-living adjustment and rounding rules for adjusted amounts. The "Make College Affordable Act of 2003" amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow deductions for qualified tuition and related expenses of eligible students. The act also makes the deduction permanent, exempting it from sunset provisions. The Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001 amendments, as per section 431, are not subject to sunset provisions. The effective date for these amendments is for payments made after December 31, 2002. SEC. 3. CREDIT FOR INTEREST ON HIGHER EDUCATION LOANS. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to include a new section for interest on higher education loans. The new section allows individuals to claim a tax credit for interest paid on qualified education loans, with a maximum credit of $1,500. The credit amount is reduced if the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income exceeds $50,000 ($100,000 for joint returns). The tax credit allowable under this section is reduced based on excess amounts, with modified adjusted gross income excluding certain sections. Inflation adjustments apply for taxable years after 2003. The tax credit amount is increased annually based on the cost-of-living adjustment. If the adjusted amount is not a multiple of $50, it will be rounded to the nearest multiple of $50. No credit is allowed if a deduction for the same individual is claimed by another taxpayer. There is a limit on the period for which the credit is allowed. The tax credit amount increases annually based on the cost-of-living adjustment and is rounded to the nearest multiple of $50. No credit is allowed if a deduction for the same individual is claimed by another taxpayer. The credit is limited to the first 60 months of interest payments on a qualified education loan. Definitions for "qualified education loan" and "dependent" are provided. No double benefit is allowed under this section. The tax credit does not allow for a double benefit if a deduction is claimed by another taxpayer. Married couples must file a joint return to qualify for the credit, and marital status is determined according to specific guidelines. The amendments made by this section apply to any qualified education loan incurred before or after the enactment of this Act, with respect to loan interest payments due after December 31, 2002.
